content.description: This is the most striking line on hogback! Starting up a a steep wall with a series of nice holds launch into an overhaning stem using the tips crack to pull into the fantastically unlikley stem. Lieback into a kneelock rest at the top of the overhang then either crimp stright up, or launch backwards to a deadpoint cross and mantle onto the "jug" rail. Both varaitions are similar in difficulty and provind a rest stance at the top of the overhang. The funs not over yet!!! finish on a slightly overhanging seam and pull right over the lip.
content.protection: this route had top ancors but they have been removed at request. bring a pad to protect sharp edges and try to get the ancor over the edge to reduce rope drag.  a few trees can be used as well as a nut or two.
content.location: Second butress left middle of the long wall. Obvious overhanging corner with red and black streaks

content.description: Obvious crack that leads to a small ledge with a block on it. Bottom is wet a lot of times but easy going moves that lead to good gear. Crux is where the finger crack starts to lead to hands.
content.location: Located on the first wall as you come down the gully betwen first and second buttres.

content.description: Start at base of blocky arete. Climb up to first bolt and then step onto face. Climb through five more bolts following small crimps. Ring anchor at top.
content.location: Immediately to the right of Hanging with Hornets.

climbs.name: Keep Your Hams In the Oven

content.description: Starts right of too many lady bugs and follow the prominent aerete. Gain big jugs through some exposed basalt crimps. Follow the aeret through techy 5.11 crimps.

climbs.name: I Turned in my Hammer Drill

content.description: this route can be as hard as 11b if you direct start. climb up and left of the roof and take the arete to the ancors.
content.protection: two bolts at the top with chains have been removed toprope off trees and nuts
content.location: second butress two the right of the chimney with a large tree at it's top

content.description: There are four ways to this climb this route. The crux on all is the virticle step and evey varaition goes at the same grade
content.location: Far west end of second butress left of Hanging With Hornets

content.description: Many variations possible on thin slabs leading to a pull through an overhang. Bolt has been added down low, which eliminates old run out
content.protection: The crack can be led with 00,0, and 1 metolius cams and a #4 stopper. One bolt.
content.location: on second buttress just left of Two Many Ladybugs

content.description: Second Buttress is home to some of the tallest and steepest climbing on Hogback. As of now there are only a few trad lines and top rope routes but they are absolutley worth the hike. The slightly remote setting combined with the amazing aesthetic of routes such as "Too Many Ladybugs", Second Buttress will undoubtly become a frequented rock climbing destination in the Marquette region.
